csse2002.security

Class KnowledgeDistribution

  • java.lang.Object
    • csse2002.security.KnowledgeDistribution
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<BigFraction>

    public class KnowledgeDistribution
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<BigFraction>
    A spy's knowledge of a Boolean-valued secret is described by a distribution describing the likelihood that the secret is true and the likelihood that the secret is false. Such a distribution is referred to as a knowledge-state. For simplicity, knowledge-states are represented simply by a BigFraction denoting the likelihood that the secret is true in the knowledge-state. (With the likelihood of the secret being false implicitly represented by the complement of that probability.)

    Through interactions with informants via two-coin channels (see TwoCoinChannel), a spy's knowledge of the secret may change, probabilistically. For example, consider a spy who is initially certain that the secret is equally likely to be true or false. Following an encounter with an informant, who communicates with her using a two-coin channel with bias 3/4 for the first coin, and 1/4 for the second, she will update her knowledge of the state based on whether or not the result of the informant's coin flip was heads or tails. With probability 1/2 the outcome will be heads and she will learn that the secret is true with probability 3/4; and with probability 1/2 the outcome will be tails and she will learn that the secret is true with probability 1/4 (and false with the complementary probability).

    This class is a mutable representation of a discrete sub-distribution on knowledge-states. Such a sub-distribution represents a mapping from knowledge-states to probabilities, in which the weight of the distribution -- the sum of the probabilities of all the knowledge states in the distribution-- must be less than or equal to one. (We allow sub-distributions so that this class can be used to build total (i.e. one-summing) distributions.)

    A KnowledgeDistribution may be used to model the likelihood that a spy has certain states of knowledge following interactions with various informants via two-coin channels. In the example above, for instance, the spy starts with a KnowledgeDistribution:

    {{true@1/2, false@1/2}@1}

    describing the fact that, with probability one, she knows the secret to be equally likely to be true or false. And following her interaction with the informant, her KnowledgeDistribution is:

    {{true@1/4, false@3/4}@1/2, {true@3/4, false@1/4}@1/2}

    If she now interacts with another informant, one that communicates with her over two-coin channel TwoCoinChannel(1/3, 1/2) if and only if her knowledge state is {true@3/4, false@1/4}, then her resulting KnowledgeDistribution will be:

    {{true@1/4, false@3/4}@1/2, {true@2/3, false@1/3}@3/16, {true@4/5, false@1/5}@5/16}

        public KnowledgeDistribution(BigFraction s)

        Parameters:

        Throws:

        public KnowledgeDistribution(KnowledgeDistribution k)
        Creates a new KnowledgeDistribution with the same knowledge-states and corresponding weights as KnowledgeDistribution k. Parameter k is unmodified by the operation, and future operations on this. Similarly, this is unmodified by future modifications to k.
        Parameters:
        k - The KnowledgeDistribution from which our new KnowledgeDistribution will be created.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If parameter k is null;

      • weight

        public BigFraction weight()
        Returns the combined probability of all the knowledge-states in the support of the KnowledgeDistribution.
        Returns:

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<BigFraction> iterator()
        Returns an iterator over the knowledge-states in the support of this distribution. The support of this distribution is defined as the knowledge-states with non-zero probability in this.

        The knowledge-states returned are represented by BigIntegers, describing the probability that the secret is true in that knowledge-state.

        The knowledge-states, represented by BigIntegers, are returned in (ascending) sorted order according to the natural ordering of BigInteger: that is, knowledge-states are returned ordered by their likelihood that the secret is true, with the knowledge-state with the smallest probability that the secret is true being returned first.

        The iterator's behaviour is not defined if the KnowledgeDistribution is modified after it has been created. (That is, don't use this method to get an iterator, modify the KnowledgeDistribution, and then try to use the iterator.)
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<BigFraction>

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns the string

        "{KS1@W1, ... , KSN@WN}",

        where N is the number of knowledge-states in the support of this (i.e. those states with a non-zero probability of occurrence), and for i in 1..N, KSi is a string representation -- described below -- of the knowledge-state in the support of this with the ith-smallest probability that the secret is true, and Wi is its corresponding probability of occurrence.

        The string representation of a knowledge-state in which the secret is true with probability P and false with the complementary probability P' is given by:

        "{true@P, false@P'}"

        where P and P' are given by the toString representation of BigFraction.

        For example, the string:

        "{{true@1/4, false@3/4}@1/2, {true@2/3, false@1/3}@3/16, {true@4/5, false@1/5}@5/16}"

        is used to represent a KnowledgeDistribution with a three-element support in which knowledge-state 1/4 occurs with probability 1/2, 2/3 occurs with probability 3/16, and 4/5 occurs with probability 5/16.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • add

        public void add(BigFraction s,
       BigFraction p)
        Increase the likelihood of knowledge-state s in this by probability p.
        Parameters:
        s - The knowledge-distribution that will have its likelihood increased.
        p - The probability by which the likelihood of s will be increased.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If either s or p are null.
        InvalidProbabilityException - If either p or s is not a probability.
        InvalidKnowledgeDistributionException - If, as a result of this operation, the weight of the KnowledgeDistribution would exceed the value one.

      • subtract

        public void subtract(BigFraction s,
            BigFraction p)
        Decreases the likelihood of knowledge-state s in this by probability p.
        Parameters:

        p - The probability by which the likelihood of s will be decreased.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If either s or p are null.
        InvalidProbabilityException - If either s or p is not a probability.
        InvalidKnowledgeDistributionException - If, as a result of this operation, the likelihood of s would fall below zero.

      • update

        public void update(ConditionalTwoCoinChannel c)
        Recall that this KnowledgeDistributin may be used to describe the likelihood of the spy being in each possible knowledge-state, following a sequence of of interactions with informants using conditional two-coin channels.

        This operation updates this KnowledgeDistribution to reflect the change of knowledge that would result from an interaction with an informant using conditional two-coin channel c.

        Recall that such an informant first checks to see if the knowledge-state of the spy is c.getCondition(). If it is, then the informant reveals the bias of both coins in c.getTwoCoinChannel() to the spy. Then, in private, the informant flips coin1 if the secret is true, and coin2 if the secret is false, and reveals the outcome of the coin flip to the spy (but not which coin has been flipped).

        If the knowledge-state of the spy is not c.getCondition(), then the informant reveals nothing and vanishes.

        Assume, for example that this knowledge distribution is currently:

        {{true@1/2, false@1/2}@1/4, {true@4/5, false@1/5}@3/4}

        Following an interaction with an informant using the conditional two-coin channel if true@1/2 then (3/4, 1/4), then the updated KnowledgeDistribution will be:

        {{true@1/4, false@3/4}@1/8, {true@3/4, false@1/4}@1/8, {true@4/5, false@1/5}@3/4}
        Parameters:
        c - The conditional two-coin channel that will be used to update this KnowledgeDistribution
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If c is null.

      • checkInv

        public boolean checkInv()
        Determines whether this knowledge sub-distribution is internally consistent.
        Returns:
        true if this KnowledgeDistribution is internally consistent, and false otherwise
